title: Mona Lisa
desc: The world's most famous painting. That enigmatic smile has captivated viewers for 500 years. Leonardo's sfumato technique creates an almost living presence. Her gaze follows you around the room.
why: The ultimate masterpiece. X-rays reveal three versions underneath - Leonardo constantly refined perfection. The landscape behind uses atmospheric perspective. Stolen in 1911, making it even more famous.

title: The Last Supper
desc: Jesus announces his betrayal at Passover meal. Disciples react in shock and confusion. Leonardo captured 13 different emotional responses in one frozen moment of drama.
why: Revolutionary one-point perspective focuses on Christ. Each apostle's gesture tells their story. Despite terrible deterioration from experimental technique, it remains psychology perfected in paint.

title: The Creation of Adam
desc: God reaches out to give Adam life on the Sistine Chapel ceiling. That nearly-touching finger gap is art history's most iconic detail. Painted while lying on scaffolding for four years.
why: The defining image of creation. Some scholars see a brain outline in God's cloak. The muscular Adam shows Renaissance humanism - man as divine creation worthy of perfect form.

title: David
desc: 17-foot marble statue of biblical David before fighting Goliath. Every muscle tense, eyes fierce with concentration. Carved from single massive block other sculptors abandoned as flawed.
why: Perfect human form in marble. Those enormous hands! That psychological intensity! Symbol of Florentine independence. Took three years of non-stop carving from one block.

title: The Birth of Venus
desc: Venus emerges full-grown from the sea on giant scallop shell. Wind gods Zephyr and Aura blow her toward shore where spring awaits with flowered cloak.
why: First major nude since antiquity - pagan mythology meets Christian Renaissance. Venus's modest pose echoes classical sculptures. Flowing hair defies gravity. Everything celebrates beauty reborn.

title: Primavera
desc: Spring personified in orange grove. Venus at centre, Three Graces dance in translucent gowns, Mercury reaches for clouds. Over 500 identifiable plant species bloom.
why: Renaissance allegory at absolute peak. Each figure represents philosophical aspects of spring. Neo-Platonic philosophy made visible. Those transparent fabrics? Technical mastery showing off.

title: School of Athens
desc: History's greatest philosophers gathered impossibly. Plato and Aristotle debate at centre, surrounded by Pythagoras, Socrates, Euclid. Renaissance meets Ancient Greece.
why: Perfect perspective and composition. Each thinker's gesture reflects philosophy - Plato points up, Aristotle gestures to earth. Michelangelo broods as Heraclitus. Leonardo is Plato. Raphael painted himself!

title: The Arnolfini Portrait
desc: Italian merchant Giovanni Arnolfini and wife in Bruges home. Convex mirror reflects entire room. Single candle burns. Dog at feet. Every object symbolic.
why: Oil painting perfected. Detail is microscopic - individual carpet threads visible! Mirror shows van Eyck himself as witness. Marriage contract in paint? Mystery endures 600 years.

title: The Garden of Earthly Delights
desc: Massive triptych - paradise, earthly pleasures run amok, horrific hell. Bizarre hybrid creatures, impossible architecture, thousands of naked figures. Bosch's wildest imagination.
why: Surrealism 400 years early! Hell's musical instruments torture sinners. Giant strawberries = fleeting pleasure. Every inch reveals bizarre details. Religious warning or celebration of pleasure?

title: Girl with a Pearl Earring
desc: Young woman in exotic blue and yellow turban turns over shoulder. That luminous pearl catches light. Dark background makes face glow. Simple, maximum impact.
why: The Dutch Mona Lisa. Vermeer's light mastery makes pearl glow from within. Who is she - servant or merchant's daughter? That glance eternally enigmatic.

title: The Night Watch
desc: Amsterdam militia assembling. Captain in black, lieutenant in yellow. Mysterious golden girl. Movement, light, theatrical drama. Revolutionary group portrait breaking all rules.
why: Baroque action painting - they're MOVING! Rembrandt's chiaroscuro creates spotlight effect. Originally larger before being trimmed for doorway. Recently restored revealing hidden details.

title: The Calling of St. Matthew
desc: Jesus enters dark tavern where Matthew counts money. Christ points, divine light streams in. Matthew points at himself - 'Who, me?' Conversion moment frozen.
why: Caravaggio invented dramatic tenebrism lighting. That pointing hand echoes Michelangelo's Adam. Street people as biblical figures was radical. Light equals divine grace visible.

title: Judith Slaying Holofernes
desc: Jewish widow beheads Assyrian general. Blood spurts. Maid helps hold him. Violent, visceral, powerful. Rape survivor's justice through art.
why: Female painter's masterpiece. More violent than Caravaggio's version. Artemisia's trauma transformed into feminist revenge art. Judith's fierce determination revolutionary.

title: Las Meninas
desc: Spanish royal court. Infanta Margarita centre with ladies-in-waiting. Velázquez paints at huge canvas. Mirror shows king and queen. Who's painting whom?
why: Most analysed painting ever. Are we where king and queen stand? Spatial complexity is mind-bending. Velázquez asserts artist's noble importance by including himself.

title: The Swing
desc: Young woman swings high while lover hides in bushes below looking up skirts. Shoe flies off. Pink dress, lush garden, frivolous pleasure.
why: Rococo's most famous. Nobleman commissioned painting of mistress on swing with him hiding below. Flying shoe = lost virtue. Fragonard's brushwork pure joy.

title: The Death of Marat
desc: Revolutionary leader Marat murdered in medicinal bath by Charlotte Corday. Simple composition, dramatic lighting. Letter and knife remain. David's friend martyred.
why: Revolutionary propaganda as high art. Composition echoes Pietà - Marat as revolutionary Christ. David painted dead friend with realism and idealization. Political art's peak.

title: The Raft of the Medusa
desc: Shipwreck survivors wave desperately at distant rescue. Dead and dying bodies. Real 1816 French naval disaster involving cannibalism. Massive canvas showing human suffering.
why: Romanticism's manifesto - emotion over classical myths. Géricault interviewed survivors, studied corpses at morgue. Composition builds from death to hope. Political controversy made it famous.

title: Liberty Leading the People
desc: Bare-breasted Liberty leads revolutionaries over barricades. Tricolor flag raised. Dead soldiers below. July Revolution 1830 celebrated. France's national symbol born.
why: Revolutionary icon. Liberty is goddess and common woman. Dying man gazes up - hope amid carnage. Delacroix the bourgeois painter joined barricades himself.

title: Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog
desc: Man on cliff looking over sea of fog and mountains. Lone figure contemplating sublime nature. German Romanticism's awe and melancholy. Individual facing infinity.
why: Romantic sublime perfected. Is he master of nature or dwarfed by it? We see his back - meant to stand beside him. Friedrich painted spiritual experience through landscape.

title: The Fighting Temeraire
desc: Old warship HMS Temeraire towed to be scrapped. Sunset blazes. Age of sail ending. Ghostly white ship pulled by black steamboat.
why: Turner's nostalgia masterpiece. Ship fought at Trafalgar with Nelson. Turner dissolving form into light predicts abstract art. Britain voted it favourite painting.

title: The Stone Breakers
desc: Old man and boy breaking stones roadside. Backbreaking labour, poverty, faces hidden. No heroism, no beauty - just reality of working-class life.
why: Revolutionary showing poverty without sentiment. No faces - anonymous workers. Courbet rejected Romantic idealization. Socialist art before socialism. Destroyed in Dresden bombing.

title: The Gleaners
desc: Three peasant women bend collecting leftover grain after harvest. Backbreaking work, monumental treatment. Rich fields behind. Poor women gathering scraps.
why: Working women given biblical scale. Critics saw dangerous socialism. Millet grew up peasant - painted his own class. Bending figures show labour's cost.

title: Olympia
desc: Nude prostitute reclines, staring boldly at viewer. Black maid brings flowers from client. Black cat. Not idealized goddess but modern working woman.
why: Caused riot at 1865 Salon! Clearly prostitute, not Venus. Direct gaze confrontational. Manet painted modern life honestly. Bridged Realism and Impressionism. Shocked Paris.

title: Impression, Sunrise
desc: Le Havre harbour at dawn through mist. Orange sun barely visible, blue water, boats as shadows. Loose brushstrokes. Named Impressionism when critic mocked it.
why: Started revolution! Critics said unfinished - just 'impression.' Monet captured fleeting light in minutes. Modern art begins with this sunrise.

title: Water Lilies
desc: Monet's pond at Giverny. Water lilies float, willows droop, sky reflects. Painted nearly blind with cataracts. 250+ paintings of same subject obsessively.
why: Series concept revolutionised art. Each captures different light, time, season. Almost abstract - predicted Abstract Expressionism decades early. Final obsession became ultimate masterpiece.

title: A Bar at the Folies-Bergère
desc: Barmaid Suzon stares at viewer with melancholy. Mirror behind shows crowded cabaret, her back, gentleman she serves. Paris nightlife's lonely glamour.
why: Manet's final masterpiece. Mirror reflection geometrically impossible - creates mystery. Her blank, tired stare = isolation amid crowds. Modern alienation's first portrait.

title: Luncheon of the Boating Party
desc: Friends dining on riverside terrace. Dappled sunlight through awning, wine glasses catch light, conversation, flirtation. Renoir's future wife Aline cuddles dog. Pure joy.
why: Impressionism's most joyful celebration. Light filtering through awning = technical triumph. Each person is Renoir's friend. Technicolor before cinema existed.

title: The Dance Class
desc: Ballet dancers rehearsing at Paris Opera. Some practice, some rest, one scratches back. Master Jules Perrot watches. Behind-the-scenes reality not performance.
why: Degas painted dancers obsessively - not performances but their labour. Unusual angles from photography influence. Captures unglamorous reality of artistic work.

title: The Starry Night
desc: Swirling night sky over Saint-Rémy village from asylum window. Cypress flames upward, stars and moon blaze. Turbulent beauty from mental torment.
why: Van Gogh's most iconic. Those cosmic swirls predict how galaxies move! Painted during breakdown - chaos made beautiful. Cypress = death, stars = eternity.

title: Café Terrace at Night
desc: Yellow café glows against cobalt Arles night sky. Cobblestone street, stars overhead. No black paint used - darkness entirely from colours. Vibrant nocturne.
why: First major nocturne without black! Yellow vs blue creates electric atmosphere. Actual café still exists in Arles! Painted during happy period before breakdown.

title: Sunflowers
desc: Bouquet of sunflowers in various life stages - full bloom to decay. Yellow on yellow. Thick impasto. Painted to decorate yellow house for Gauguin.
why: Van Gogh's signature worldwide. Used chrome yellow now browning with age. Each flower shows complete life cycle. Painted rapidly with passion - every brushstroke visible.

title: Wheat Field with Crows
desc: Turbulent golden wheat under stormy sky. Black crows fly ominously. Three paths diverge into field. Painted weeks before suicide. Dark, violent beauty.
why: Possibly last painting before death. Paths lead nowhere - symbol of confusion. Crows = death. Violent brushstrokes show psychological torment. Nature as psychological landscape.

title: A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte
desc: Parisians relaxing by Seine. Entirely tiny dots - pointillism. Took two years, thousands of dots. Scientific colour theory made art.
why: Pointillism perfected. Stand close - see dots. Step back - forms emerge. Critique of bourgeois leisure? Monkey on leash suggests satire. Revolutionary technique.

title: The Card Players
desc: Provençal peasants playing cards. Solid, blocky forms. No distractions. Pure concentration on geometric structure and relationships.
why: Bridge from Impressionism to Cubism. Cézanne's 'little cubes' reducing forms to geometry. Made five versions. Simple scene = form study. One sold $250 million!

title: Mont Sainte-Victoire
desc: Mountain near Aix painted obsessively 60+ times. Geometric landscape breaking nature into colour planes. Blues, greens, ochres build structure. Late versions almost abstract.
why: Painted same subject endlessly to understand form. Breaking nature into geometry directly led to Cubism. Cézanne said nature is cylinders, spheres, cones. Picasso and Braque studied these.

title: The Scream
desc: Figure holds head screaming on bridge. Sky swirls blood red and orange. Oslo fjord below. Munch's anxiety made visible. Modern alienation's icon.
why: Existential anxiety in art. Munch felt 'scream of nature' walking at sunset. Mental illness, sister's death influenced. Four versions exist. One stolen twice! Universal anguish symbol.

title: The Kiss
desc: Couple embraces, covered in golden patterns - rectangles for him, circular flowers for her. Gold leaf background. They kneel on flower field at cliff edge.
why: Klimt's golden period peak. Real gold leaf used! Masculine rectangles and feminine circles unite. Erotic yet decorative. Byzantine influence. Lovers isolated in golden universe.

title: Woman with a Hat
location: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
desc: Matisse's wife Amélie in elaborate hat. Wild, unnatural colours - green nose, orange hair, purple shadows. Critics called them 'fauves' (wild beasts). Colour liberated.
why: Fauvism's scandalous debut at 1905 Salon. Critics mocked 'savage' colours. Matisse freed colour from description. His wife barely recognised herself! Gertrude Stein bought it.

title: The Dance
desc: Five nude figures dance in circle against blue and green. Pure joy, movement, rhythm. Only three colours - red, blue, green. Primitive ecstasy in modern form.
why: Matisse's simplified form and colour masterpiece. Russian collector commissioned it. Red figures, blue sky, green earth - that's all you need. Circle = life cycle.

title: Les Demoiselles d'Avignon
desc: Five nude prostitutes from Barcelona brothel. African mask faces, fragmented geometric bodies. Multiple viewpoints simultaneously. Destroyed traditional perspective. Cubism born.
why: Most revolutionary since Renaissance! Multiple viewpoints destroys 500 years of perspective. African art influence. Even Matisse and Braque shocked. Changed everything. Picasso kept it rolled up years.

title: Guernica
desc: Spanish Civil War bombing horror. Screaming horse, dismembered bodies, grieving mother, bull, light bulb. Black, white, grey. 25 feet wide. War's horror in fragmented forms.
why: 20th century's greatest anti-war painting. Nazis bombed civilian Guernica. Picasso painted massive protest. Bull, horse, light = Spanish symbols. Touring raised Spanish Republic funds. Never loses power.

title: The Persistence of Memory
desc: Melting pocket watches drape over tree branch and strange flesh form in barren landscape. Time fluid. Ants crawl on closed watch. Dalí's subconscious dreamscape.
why: Surrealism's most iconic image. Dalí said inspired by melting Camembert! Time as fluid, relative - Einstein visualised. Hard technique, soft subject. Ants = decay. Tiny - only 9 inches!

title: The Son of Man
desc: Man in bowler hat and overcoat. Green apple floats hiding face. Magritte's mystery - visible hiding invisible. Everyday object made strange.
why: Magritte's most famous. We want to see what's hidden. Apple both reveals and conceals. Everything visible hides something. Business suit = conformity, apple = temptation, face = unknowability.

title: American Gothic
desc: Iowa farmer and daughter (sister and dentist actually) pose before Gothic Revival farmhouse. Pitchfork, stern expressions. Wood's sister Nan and dentist modeled. American Midwest icon.
why: Most parodied American painting. Meant as satire of small-town narrow-mindedness or celebration of rural values? Ambiguous. The Gothic window inspired entire painting. Defines American Regionalism.

title: Nighthawks
desc: Late-night diner on empty NYC corner. Three customers, one worker, harsh fluorescent light. Outside is darkness. Urban isolation, loneliness. No door visible - trapped inside.
why: Defines American urban alienation. Painted after Pearl Harbour - wartime anxiety. Based on Greenwich Village diner. No door = can't enter or leave. Fluorescent light = modernity's harsh glare. Endlessly influential.

title: Christina's World
desc: Woman with polio crawls through field toward distant farmhouse. Christina Olson, Wyeth's neighbour, was real person. Pink dress, dry grass, remote buildings. Determination and isolation.
why: American art's most famous image of isolation and perseverance. Wyeth's neighbour couldn't walk - crawled everywhere. That distant house = unreachable home. The grass detail took months. Wyeth's masterpiece.

title: Campbell's Soup Cans
desc: 32 canvases showing every Campbell's soup flavor. Mechanical repetition, consumer culture celebrated. Warhol said he ate Campbell's soup every day for lunch. Mass production as art.
why: Pop Art's defining work. High art from commercial imagery. 32 flavors = complete line. Warhol removed artist's hand - silk-screened like advertising. Art and commerce merge. Changed everything.

title: Marilyn Diptych
desc: 50 images of Marilyn Monroe after her suicide. Left side bright colour, right fading to black. Silk-screened repetition. Celebrity as product, death as media event.
why: Warhol's comment on celebrity culture. Made within weeks of Marilyn's death. Colour fades to black = life to death. Repetition = mass media saturation. She's both there and not there - ghost in machine.

title: Whaam!
desc: Fighter jet shoots enemy plane. Comic book Ben-Day dots enlarged to canvas. Speech bubble 'WHAAM!' War violence as comic book. Two panels like comic strip.
why: Pop Art taking comics seriously. War violence aestheticized into pop imagery. Lichtenstein hand-painted Ben-Day dots from printing process. Low art elevated to high art. Questions what deserves museum.

title: No. 5, 1948
desc: Drip painting - yellow, white, grey on brown. Pollock dripped and splattered paint while walking around canvas on floor. No brushes touched canvas. Action painting perfected.
why: Most expensive painting ever sold privately - $140 million! Pollock's revolutionary drip technique. The painting is record of artist's movement - dance frozen. Sold to private collector immediately.

title: Autumn Rhythm (Number 30)
desc: Black, white, brown drips on unprimed canvas. 17 feet wide. Pollock circled canvas, dripping paint from sticks and hardened brushes. All-over composition - no focal point.
why: Action painting at peak. The painting is physical record of Pollock's movements. No sketch, no plan - pure improvisation like jazz. Surface is uniform energy field. Influenced by Native American sand painting.

title: Woman I
desc: Grotesque, aggressive female figure. Huge eyes, bared teeth, massive breasts. Violent brushwork, garish colours. De Kooning scraped off and repainted for 18 months. Abstract Expressionism meets figuration.
why: Shocked Abstract Expressionist purists - why return to figure? De Kooning's women are fierce, not passive muses. That smile is both alluring and terrifying. Took 18 months of scraping and repainting.

title: Orange and Yellow
desc: Two rectangles - orange on top, yellow below - float on orange field. Edges blur and vibrate. Large scale meant for close viewing. Pure colour field creating emotional response.
why: Rothko's colour field at peak. Meant to be viewed close up - immersive experience. Colours vibrate and breathe. Rothko wanted paintings to evoke spiritual transcendence through colour alone.

title: Seagram Murals
desc: Series of dark reds and maroons for Four Seasons restaurant. Rothko refused to deliver them - didn't want art in restaurant. Kept money anyway. Dark, chapel-like atmosphere.
why: Rothko couldn't stand idea of art where rich people ate. Kept the money, refused delivery. The dark reds and blacks show his turn toward darkness before suicide. Now in Tate's Rothko Room.

title: Flag
desc: American flag painted in encaustic on canvas. Is it painting or flag? Johns made it after dreaming of flag. Symbol vs object question. Pop Art precursor.
why: Is it painting of flag or flag itself? Johns questions representation. Made after dream. Used encaustic (wax) technique. Inspired by seeing flags everywhere in 1950s America. Bridge from Abstract Expressionism to Pop.

title: Target with Four Faces
desc: Target with plaster casts of faces in boxes above. Everyday symbol turned mysterious. Target suggests aiming, shooting. Faces = anonymous humanity as targets?
why: Johns taking everyday objects and making them strange. Targets are about looking, aiming. Faces add human element. Neo-Dada questioning Abstract Expressionism's pure abstraction.

title: Untitled (Perfect Lovers)
desc: Two identical clocks side by side, synchronized. Eventually they fall out of sync as batteries die at different rates. About artist and partner dying of AIDS. Time, love, death.
why: Two lovers, two clocks - start together, end separately. Heartbreaking AIDS crisis memorial. The clocks will eventually differ - death comes for us all, but not together. Simple, devastating conceptual art.

title: One and Three Chairs
desc: Physical chair, photograph of that chair, dictionary definition of 'chair.' Three representations of chair-ness. Idea vs object. Language vs reality.
why: Conceptual art's key work. Which is 'real' chair - object, image, or definition? All three describe chair differently. Art as idea not object. Influenced by philosophy.

title: The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living
desc: 14-foot tiger shark in formaldehyde in glass tank. Death preserved, made visible. Hirst's most infamous work. Shocking, memorable, conceptual.
why: Sensation! Real dead shark in tank. We can't comprehend our own death - here's death made physical, preserved. Cost $50,000 to make, sold for millions. YBA movement's shock tactics.

title: My Bed
desc: Emin's actual unmade bed with dirty sheets, condoms, stained underwear, vodka bottles, cigarettes. Aftermath of depression. Raw, confessional, controversial.
why: Emin's bed after suicidal depression. Everything present - blood, bodily fluids, despair made physical. Caused scandal at Turner Prize. Autobiography as art. Uncomfortable truth.

title: Balloon Dog (Orange)
desc: 10-foot tall stainless steel balloon dog in mirror-polished orange. Looks like balloon but weighs tons. Childhood joy in permanent, precious material. One sold $58 million.
why: Most expensive living artist work at time. Childhood balloon animal made monumental and permanent. Koons elevates kitsch to high art. That mirror surface reflects viewer - we're part of art.

title: Rabbit
desc: Stainless steel inflatable rabbit. Mirror finish reflects surroundings. Childhood toy monumentalized. Sold $91 million - most expensive by living artist.
why: Koons's breakthrough. Cheap inflatable made precious metal sculpture. That mirrored surface means you see yourself - the viewer completes the work. Sold for $91 million in 2019!

title: Untitled (Your body is a battleground)
desc: Black and white female face split down middle, text overlaid: 'Your body is a battleground.' Abortion rights protest. Advertising techniques for political message.
why: Feminist art icon. Women's reproductive rights. Made for 1989 pro-choice march. Kruger uses advertising language to critique power. That bold text, that split face. Art as activism.

title: The Dinner Party
desc: Triangular table with 39 place settings for important women in history - from prehistory to Georgia O'Keeffe. Each plate has unique design, often vaginal imagery. Feminist art landmark.
why: Monumental feminist artwork celebrating women erased from history. Took five years, hundreds of volunteers. Each plate unique. Heritage Floor lists 999 more women. Controversial for explicit imagery.

title: Mama Ray
desc: Giant bronze spider - 30 feet tall. Carries marble eggs in sac. Mother as protector and predator. Bourgeois's tribute to her weaver mother. Monumental, terrifying, beautiful.
why: Bourgeois made these massive spider sculptures in her 80s! Mother spider protects but can kill. The eggs are precious yet trapped. Spiders weave like her mother. Feminism, motherhood, fear combined.

title: Fountain
desc: Porcelain urinal signed 'R. Mutt' and submitted as sculpture. Rejected from exhibition. Duchamp's ready-made - everyday object becomes art by artist's choice. Conceptual art born.
why: Most influential artwork of 20th century? Duchamp said artist's choice makes something art. A urinal! Shocked everyone. Original lost, replicas made later. Questioned 'what is art?' fundamentally.

title: L.H.O.O.Q.
desc: Postcard of Mona Lisa with penciled mustache and goatee. Title is pun in French sounding like 'she has hot ass.' Duchamp mocking art's sacred cow.
why: Ultimate Dada provocation - defacing Mona Lisa! Questions art reverence. Title's sexual pun. The moustache makes Leonardo's masterpiece absurd. Duchamp's cheek changed art.

title: The Treachery of Images
desc: Realistic pipe painted above text 'Ceci n'est pas une pipe' (This is not a pipe). Of course it's not - it's painting of pipe! Image vs reality.
why: Philosophy in image. It's NOT a pipe - it's representation. Can't smoke a painting! Questions nature of art, representation, reality. Magritte making us think about thinking.

title: The Elephants
desc: Elephants with impossibly thin spider legs carry obelisks. Swans reflected as elephants in water. Dalí's nuclear mysticism period. Fragility supporting massive weight.
why: Post-war anxiety as distorted strength. Thin legs = atomic age fragility. Elephants inspired by Bernini sculpture. Everything in Dalí is symbolic, dreamlike, obsessive.

title: The Burning Giraffe
desc: Female figure with drawers in body supported by crutches. Giraffe aflame in background. Spanish Civil War anxiety. Freudian symbols. Premonition of catastrophe.
why: Painted as Spain collapsed into war. Burning giraffe = horror premonition. Drawers = hidden psyche parts. Crutches = need for support. Dalí processing war trauma through dream.

title: Girl Before a Mirror
desc: Marie-Thérèse Walter contemplates mirror reflection. Bright colours, patterns, multiple profiles. Day face vs night face. Picasso's most decorative Cubist work.
why: Picasso at most colorful. Mirror shows inner self - darker, more complex. Multiple views simultaneously. Matisse influence visible in patterns. Decorated domesticity. Psychology and beauty.

title: Three Musicians
desc: Harlequin, Pierrot, monk play music together. Flat, collage-like shapes in synthetic Cubism. Commedia dell'arte characters. Picasso and dead friends - Apollinaire, Max Jacob.
why: Synthetic Cubism perfected - flat shapes reassembled. Three musicians are Picasso's friends. Commedia dell'arte meets modern geometry. Elegy for lost friendships. Two versions exist.

title: Violin and Candlestick
location: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
desc: Analytical Cubism - violin fragmented into geometric planes. Browns, tans, grays. Multiple viewpoints. Object from all angles simultaneously on flat surface.
why: Analytical Cubism peak - breaking objects into facets. Braque and Picasso 'roped together like mountaineers.' Can find violin if you look. Pure visual investigation.

title: Broadway Boogie Woogie
desc: Grid of primary colours - yellow, red, blue - with small coloured rectangles. Mondrian's love of NYC and jazz. Boogie-woogie rhythm in paint. His last complete painting.
why: Mondrian's NYC love letter. Grid = Manhattan streets, rhythm = boogie-woogie jazz he loved. More complex than earlier grids. Pure abstraction expressing city's energy. Died shortly after.

title: Composition with Red, Blue, and Yellow
desc: Black grid lines dividing canvas. Primary colours fill some rectangles - red, blue, yellow. White negative space. Pure abstraction reduced to essentials. Mondrian's signature style.
why: Mondrian reducing art to pure elements - primary colours, straight lines, right angles. Influenced by theosophy - seeking universal truth. His grids influenced everything - architecture, fashion, design.

title: Black Square
desc: Black square on white background. Pure geometric abstraction. Zero degree of painting. Malevich's 'supremacy of pure feeling.' Hung in icon corner at exhibition.
why: Zero degree of painting - can't get more abstract. Malevich said represented 'supremacy of pure feeling.' Hung where Russian Orthodox icons go. Revolutionary rejection of representation. Suprematism born.

title: White on White
desc: White square on white background. Barely visible. Malevich pushing Suprematism to limit. Pure sensation beyond objects. Spiritual abstraction.
why: Taking abstraction to logical extreme - can barely see it! White square on white. Suprematism's endpoint. Can't go further without disappearing entirely. Spiritual, philosophical painting.

title: Composition VIII
desc: Geometric shapes - circles, triangles, lines - float in space. Kandinsky believed shapes and colours have spiritual power. Visual music - synesthesia made visible.
why: Kandinsky pioneered pure abstraction. Believed art should be like music - pure form and colour without subject. Synesthesia - he 'saw' colours when hearing music. Bauhaus teaching influenced this.

title: Yellow-Red-Blue
desc: Left side warm colours and geometric chaos, right side cool blues and controlled forms. Kandinsky exploring hot vs cold, chaos vs order. Visual music theory applied.
why: Kandinsky's colour theory masterpiece. Yellow = earthly, chaos. Blue = spiritual, order. Red mediates between. Like musical composition - visual symphony of colour relationships.

title: The Bride Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors, Even
desc: Large glass construction - bride above, bachelor machine below. Never touch. Oil, lead, dust on glass panels. 'Large Glass' - Duchamp's most complex work. Erotic mechanization.
why: Duchamp's most enigmatic masterpiece. Bride and bachelors separated by glass - desire never consummated. Took 8 years. Cracked in transport - Duchamp liked cracks, kept them. Mechanical eroticism. Inexhaustible interpretation.

title: The Treachery of Images (This is Not a Pipe)
desc: Pipe with text 'Ceci n'est pas une pipe.' Challenges representation. It's not a pipe - it's painting of pipe. Philosophy of signs and meaning.
why: Questions how images and words relate to reality. Famous for causing viewers to question what they see. Magritte's clearest philosophical statement. Still debated by philosophers.

title: Number 1A, 1948
desc: Drip painting - all-over composition. Pollock walked around canvas on floor dripping paint. No beginning, no end, no focal point. Pure action recorded.
why: Action painting exemplified. The painting IS the record of Pollock's dance around canvas. No composition, just energy field. Influenced by Native American sand painting and Jungian unconscious.

title: One: Number 31, 1950
desc: 17 feet wide. Black, white, grey drips on bare canvas. Monumental all-over composition. Pollock at height of powers. Meant to be immersive - stand close.
why: Pollock's largest, most ambitious work at peak of powers. 17 feet makes it environmental - meant to surround viewer. The paint skeins layer and interlace infinitely. Museum-scale painting.

title: Vir Heroicus Sublimis
desc: 18-foot wide red field with five vertical 'zips' (Newman's term). Meant to be viewed close - overwhelming sublime experience. Pure colour field.
why: Newman's sublime - spiritual experience through massive colour field. Those 'zips' (vertical lines) activate the red. Title means 'Man, Heroic and Sublime.' Stand close - it fills vision. Transcendent.

title: Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue III
desc: Huge panels of red, yellow strip, blue strip. Dominant red field. Newman asserting primary colour's emotional power. Famously attacked and slashed by vandal.
why: Newman's colour field monumentality. Attacked by visitor who slashed it! Restoration controversial. Newman proving primary colours enough for sublime experience. Title challenges viewer to face pure colour.

title: Lavender Mist: Number 1, 1950
location: National Gallery of Art, Washington DC
desc: Drip painting in white, silver, black, blue, pink. No lavender actually! Subtle colour harmony. 7+ feet wide. Pollock dripped, poured, splattered paint.
why: Pollock's most expensive sold work at auction time. Despite title no lavender - Pollock's dealer named it. The webs of paint create depth despite flatness. All-over composition perfected.

title: Blue Poles
desc: Drip painting with eight blue poles/lines. Caused scandal when Australia paid record price. Pollock's late style - vertical structure organizing chaos.
why: Australia's controversial purchase for record $2 million in 1973. Now worth $350+ million! Blue poles structure the drip chaos. Late Pollock introducing figuration back into abstraction.

title: Mountains and Sea
location: National Gallery of Art, Washington DC
desc: Stain painting - Frankenthaler poured thinned paint onto raw canvas. Colours soak in, become one with canvas. Landscape suggested by colours flowing. Changed painting.
why: Revolutionary technique - pouring thin paint onto unprimed canvas. Paint stains into fabric. Influenced Kenneth Noland and Morris Louis. Colour Field painting born from this technique. Abstract landscape.

title: Elegy to the Spanish Republic No. 110
desc: Black ovoid and rectangular forms on white. Motherwell's 40-year series about Spanish Civil War. Elegy means funeral song - mourning democracy's death in Spain.
why: Motherwell's lifelong obsession - made 150+ Elegies. Black forms = death, white = absence. Abstract memorial to Spanish Republic destroyed by Franco. Simple forms, profound meaning.

title: Canyon
desc: Combine painting - stuffed bald eagle attached to painted canvas with pillow below. Eagle was illegal to own (endangered species). Rauschenberg didn't care. Art and life combined.
why: Most controversial combine - that's real stuffed eagle (illegal to own). Rauschenberg mixing painting and sculpture and found objects. Art and life boundaries destroyed. Legal issues prevented sale for decades.

title: Bed
desc: Rauschenberg's own pillow, quilt, sheet splashed with paint and hung vertical. Bed becomes painting. Shocked 1950s - is it vandalism? Combines painting and real life.
why: Rauschenberg took his actual bed, painted it, hung it on wall. Scandalized 1950s audience. Is it painting or sculpture or neither? Breaking all boundaries. Bridge from Abstract Expressionism to Pop.

title: Untitled (I shop therefore I am)
desc: Red rectangle with text 'I shop therefore I am' - parody of Descartes. Kruger's advertising-style text critiquing consumer culture. Feminism meets consumerism critique.
why: Kruger's bold graphic style critiquing consumer capitalism. Parody of Descartes 'I think therefore I am' - now we are what we buy. Her work influenced street art, graphic design, activism.

title: Shot Marilyns
desc: Series of Marilyn silkscreens in bright colours. Woman actually shot them with gun! Made Warhol nervous. Celebrity, death, pop culture. Marilyn as commodity.
why: Visitor shot bullet through stack of Marilyns! Warhol treated as art - 'Shot Marilyns.' Celebrity as reproducible commodity. Death makes her more valuable. Pop Art's dark side.

title: Eight Elvises
desc: Eight repeating images of Elvis with gun from Western movie. Silkscreen repetition. Elvis as consumer product. Sold for $100 million privately - one of Warhol's most expensive.
why: Celebrity as endless repetition. Elvis duplicated like products on assembly line. Death and guns lurk in pop culture. Sold for $100 million+! Warhol turning celebrity into commodity art.

title: Oxidation Paintings
desc: Warhol and friends urinated on copper paint. Urine oxidized copper creating abstract patterns. Parody of Abstract Expressionism. Literally pissing on art history.
why: Warhol's ultimate parody - pissing on Abstract Expressionism! Bodily fluid becomes painting process. Random patterns from oxidation. Called them 'piss paintings.' Warhol's dark humor.

title: Untitled (Skull)
desc: Massive skull in acrylic and oil stick on canvas. Black face skull with exposed teeth. Graffiti energy meets fine art. Basquiat's signature crown. Death and racial identity.
why: Basquiat from street graffiti to auction records. This sold for $110 million! That skull references mortality and Black death. Graffiti energy in high art. Tragic - died at 27 of overdose.

title: Untitled
desc: Devil figure with crown. Text fragments, symbols, energetic marks. Basquiat's punk energy. Sold for $110 million - one of most expensive paintings ever at auction.
why: Basquiat's most expensive work. Street art meets Old Masters. That crown his signature - claiming kingship in art world. Text and image combined. Raw energy and sophistication. Died tragically young.

title: Puppy
desc: 43-foot tall West Highland Terrier puppy covered in flowers. Steel structure with flowering plants. Changes with seasons. Monumental cute. Outside Bilbao museum.
why: Koons's largest permanent work. Puppy covered in 70,000 flowers! Structure holds irrigation system. Kitsch monumentalized. Guards discovered terrorists planting bombs under it. Survived terrorism attempt!

title: Tulips
desc: Huge mirror-polished stainless steel tulips. Balloon animal aesthetic. Gift to France after Charlie Hebdo attack. 34 feet tall. Controversial memorial.
why: Gift to France after Paris terror attacks. Mirror surface reflects viewers and surroundings. Koons's balloon aesthetic meets memorial function. Controversial - critics said too kitschy for massacre memorial.

title: Sleeping Venus
desc: Reclining nude Venus asleep in landscape. First reclining nude in Renaissance. Titian may have finished it after Giorgione died young. Inspired countless later nudes.
why: First major reclining nude - established entire genre. Giorgione died young at 32 of plague. Titian his student finished it. Inspired Titian's Venus of Urbino, Manet's Olympia, centuries of reclining nudes.

title: Venus of Urbino
desc: Reclining nude Venus gazes at viewer. Small dog sleeps at feet. Servants in background. Based on Giorgione's Sleeping Venus but awake, aware, engaging viewer directly.
why: More erotic than Giorgione's sleeping version - she looks at us! That direct gaze was provocative. Influenced every reclining nude after. Manet's Olympia directly references this. Titian's colour mastery.

title: Bacchus and Ariadne
desc: Bacchus leaps from chariot toward abandoned Ariadne. Drunken revelers, leopards pulling chariot. Dynamic movement, brilliant colour. Titian's movement and colour mastery.
why: Titian's most dynamic composition. Bacchus mid-leap - impossible pose held frozen. Those blues and reds! Painted for Duke of Ferrara's study. Action, emotion, colour perfection.

title: The Rape of Europa
desc: Zeus as bull abducts Europa across sea. Her pink scarf flies. Cupids ride fish. Late Titian - loose, energetic brushwork. Mythological violence rendered beautifully.
why: Late Titian's painterly freedom. Look close - brushwork is loose, sketchy almost. Influenced Rubens, Velázquez. That pink scarf against stormy sky. Titian at 70+ painting with unprecedented freedom.

title: The Crucifixion
desc: Isenheim Altarpiece centerpiece. Christ's body wracked with pain, covered in boils and thorns. Most gruesome crucifixion ever painted. Painted for hospital treating skin diseases.
why: Most harrowing crucifixion in art. Christ's suffering made viscerally real - body covered in wounds, boils, thorns. For hospital patients with skin diseases - their suffering shared with Christ. Northern Renaissance Gothic horror.

title: The Ghent Altarpiece (Adoration of the Mystic Lamb)
artist: Jan van Eyck and Hubert van Eyck
desc: Massive altarpiece - open shows Mystic Lamb, closed shows Annunciation. Jan and Hubert van Eyck. Stolen multiple times including by Nazis. 20 panels of oil painting perfection.
why: One of history's most important artworks. Northern Renaissance oil technique perfection. Stolen six times! Nazis took it. One panel still missing since 1934. Adam and Eve panels are life-size nudes. Pristine after recent restoration.

title: The Return of the Prodigal Son
desc: Biblical parable - son returns home ragged and defeated. Father embraces him tenderly. Rembrandt's late masterpiece. Painted blind in poverty year before death. Forgiveness and mercy.
why: Rembrandt's final masterpiece - painted nearly blind before death. That embrace! Father's hands on son's back - tenderness despite son's betrayal. Rembrandt himself was prodigal - bankrupt, family dead. Autobiographical. That red - all Rembrandt had left.

title: Self-Portrait with Two Circles
desc: Rembrandt aged 59, palette and brushes. Two mysterious circles on wall behind. Late self-portrait - honest, aged, wise. One of 40+ self-portraits tracking his life.
why: One of Rembrandt's final self-portraits. No flattery - shows age honestly. Those mysterious circles behind - compass marks? Halo? Unknown. Palette and brushes assert identity as painter. 40+ self-portraits = autobiography in paint.

title: The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp
desc: Surgeon dissects cadaver's arm while guild members watch. Dramatic lighting, psychological engagement. Rembrandt's breakthrough group portrait. Medical procedure as drama.
why: Rembrandt's breakthrough commission at 26. Group portrait made dramatic - not static line-up. That lighting! The cadaver's arm dissected. Some looking, some at textbook, some at viewer. Science as spectacle.

title: The Jewish Bride
desc: Couple in golden light. Man's hand on woman's chest tenderly. Who are they? Jewish couple? Biblical Isaac and Rebecca? Unknown. Rembrandt's late style - thick paint, glowing light, intimacy.
why: Late Rembrandt masterpiece. Who are they? Title added later. That touch is tender, intimate. Paint is thick, sculptural. Van Gogh said he'd give 10 years of life to sit before it for 2 weeks. Love made visible.

title: Susanna and the Elders
desc: Young Susanna bathing, harassed by two old men. She recoils in genuine fear. Artemisia at 17 painting harassment - year before her own rape. Female perspective on male violence.
why: Painted at 17, year before her rape by art teacher. Susanna's distress is real - not eroticized like male versions. Female artist showing harassment's reality. Artemisia's breakthrough work. Signed prominently.

title: Self-Portrait as the Allegory of Painting
desc: Artemisia painting herself painting - woman as Painting personified. Female artist asserting power. One of few female self-portraits as artist working.
why: Female artist as Painting itself - extraordinary claim in male-dominated field. Only woman could embody Painting as female. Artemisia asserting her identity and importance. Revolutionary self-portrait.

title: The Burial of the Count of Orgaz
desc: Two realms - earthly burial below, heavenly glory above. Saints Stephen and Augustine lower Count's body. Heaven opens with Christ, Mary, saints. El Greco's masterpiece in Toledo.
why: El Greco's masterpiece. Two worlds - earth and heaven - connected. Elongated figures, mystical light, Spanish intensity. Count's soul rises to heaven. Painted for burial chapel in Toledo. Still in situ!

title: View of Toledo
desc: Toledo under stormy sky. Dark clouds, dramatic light, city on hill. El Greco's adopted Spanish city. Expressionistic landscape - not realistic but emotional.
why: One of first landscapes as pure subject. Toledo under apocalyptic sky. Not topographically accurate - El Greco moved buildings for composition. Expressionism 300 years early. That storm!

title: The Burial of the Sardine
desc: Carnival celebration - masked figures dance around banner. Chaos, darkness, celebration becoming sinister. Goya's late pessimistic vision. Joy corrupted.
why: Goya's dark vision of Spanish celebration. Carnival becomes nightmare. Those masks! Goya went deaf, moved to isolation, painted horrors. Spanish tradition seen through embittered eyes.

title: The Third of May 1808
desc: French soldiers execute Spanish civilians. Man in white arms raised, about to die. Lantern lights scene. Firing squad faceless. Anti-war painting showing atrocity's horror.
why: One of greatest anti-war paintings. Spanish uprising against Napoleon crushed. That man in white - Christ-like, arms raised, facing death. Soldiers faceless machines. Influenced Manet's Execution, Picasso's Guernica. War crime documented.

title: Saturn Devouring His Son
desc: Greek god Saturn eating his child raw. Goya's Black Paintings from house walls - painted in isolation, deaf, bitter. Horror, madness, darkness. Old age fearing mortality.
why: Goya's darkest work. Painted on his house walls! Saturn = time devouring all. Goya was old, deaf, isolated. These Black Paintings show descent into darkness. Transferred to canvas after death. Unbearable to look at - that's the point.

title: The Sleep of Reason Produces Monsters
desc: Man asleep at desk surrounded by flying demons, owls, bats. Caption: 'The sleep of reason produces monsters.' Enlightenment's limits. When reason sleeps, monsters emerge.
why: From Goya's Caprichos prints satirizing Spanish society. When reason sleeps, imagination produces monsters. Enlightenment critique - reason alone insufficient. Those bats and owls! Goya's own nightmares made visible.

title: The Hay Wain
desc: Rural Suffolk scene - cart crosses stream, cottage, trees, clouds. Constable's beloved English countryside. Fresh observation of light and weather. Naturalism.
why: English landscape elevated to high art. Constable's direct observation of nature, sketches outdoors. Those clouds! Studied meteorology. Influenced French Impressionists. Made landscape painting respectable subject.

title: The Opening of the Fifth Seal
desc: Apocalyptic vision - Saint John witnesses souls receiving white robes. Elongated figures writhe. Stormy sky, mystical light. El Greco's visionary intensity.
why: El Greco's most mystical, modern-looking work. Almost abstract - those elongated bodies! Cut down in 1880s. Apocalyptic vision from Revelation. Influenced Picasso. Pure expressionistic power.

title: A Rake's Progress
desc: Eight paintings showing young man's decline from inheritance to debauchery to madhouse. Hogarth's moral narrative. English satire tradition.
why: Hogarth invented sequential narrative art - precursor to comics! Tom Rakewell inherits fortune, wastes it on gambling, prostitutes, ends in madhouse. Each painting tells chapter. Morality through entertainment. Opera made from it!

title: Marriage A-la-Mode
desc: Six paintings satirizing arranged marriage between nouveau-riche merchant's daughter and broke aristocrat. Ends in disaster. Hogarth's social satire.
why: Hogarth's sharpest social satire. Arranged marriage for money leads to mutual infidelity, murder, suicide. Every detail tells story. Hogarth as social critic - exposing aristocratic hypocrisy.

title: The Swing
desc: Young woman swings high while lover hides in bushes below looking up skirts. Her shoe flies off. Pink dress, lush garden, frivolous pleasure.
why: Rococo's most famous. Nobleman commissioned painting of mistress on swing with him hiding below. Flying shoe = lost virtue. Fragonard's brushwork pure joy.

title: Ophelia
desc: Ophelia drowns singing in stream. Flowers everywhere - each symbolic. Model Elizabeth Siddal lay in bath for months - caught pneumonia. Pre-Raphaelite detail obsession. Shakespeare made real.
why: Pre-Raphaelite masterpiece! Model nearly died posing in cold bath. Every flower symbolic - pansies for thought, violets for faithfulness. That dress floating! Medieval detail meets Victorian melodrama. Siddal later married Rossetti, died young.

title: Lady of Shalott
desc: Cursed lady in boat floating to Camelot to die. Tennyson's poem visualised. Pre-Raphaelite medieval romance. That tapestry, those candles. Doomed beauty.
why: Victorian medieval fantasy perfected! Tennyson's tragic heroine. Curse makes her die if she looks directly at Camelot. Those three candles - one blown out = death coming. Pre-Raphaelite tragic beauty obsession.

title: Proserpine
desc: Persephone with pomegranate - eating it dooms her to Hades. Jane Morris modeled - Rossetti's obsession. Pre-Raphaelite beauty and doom. That smoldering gaze.
why: Rossetti painting his married lover Jane Morris obsessively. Persephone doomed by pomegranate - Jane doomed by affair? Pre-Raphaelite mixing mythology and Victorian melodrama. That intense gaze! Rossetti's fixation visible.

title: Beata Beatrix
desc: Dante's Beatrice dying. Rossetti painted wife Elizabeth Siddal after her suicide. Red dove brings poppy - opium that killed her. Memorial to dead wife. Grief made art.
why: Rossetti's dead wife memorial. Siddal died of laudanum overdose - suicide? That poppy! Red dove of death. Beatrice = Siddal. Rossetti's guilt and grief. Pre-Raphaelite tragedy made personal.

title: The Beloved
desc: Bride surrounded by attendants. Song of Solomon referenced. Rossetti's sensual spiritual vision. That copper hair! Interracial attendants unusual for Victorian art.
why: Rossetti's Biblical bride. Song of Solomon - 'My beloved is mine.' That red hair! Black attendant holding perfume - progressive for Victorian racism. Pre-Raphaelite sensuality meeting spirituality.

title: The Awakening Conscience
desc: Kept woman rises from lover's lap seeing light. Mirror reflects garden - escape to purity. Every object symbolic - cat with bird, tangled yarn. Victorian moral tale. Fallen woman's redemption.
why: Victorian moral painting! She's his mistress - that's why no wedding ring! She sees light through window - moral awakening! Every detail symbolic. Cat kills bird = lost innocence. Pre-Raphaelite detail serving moral message.

title: The Light of the World
desc: Christ with lantern knocks on overgrown door. Door has no handle - opens only from inside. Religious allegory. Hunt's evangelical vision. Victorian spirituality.
why: Victorian religious icon! Christ knocking at soul's door. No outside handle - must be opened from within. That overgrown door = souls neglecting Christ. Toured world as religious blockbuster. Pre-Raphaelite technique serving religion.

title: The Scapegoat
desc: Goat by Dead Sea carrying sins. Hunt painted actual Dead Sea location despite danger. Biblical literalism. That suffering goat! Pre-Raphaelite obsession with authenticity.
why: Hunt painted it AT the Dead Sea! Travelled to Palestine risking death. Scapegoat bearing sins dies alone. That landscape! Pre-Raphaelite insistence on authentic locations. Goat literally suffered - Hunt's religious intensity.

title: The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple
desc: Young Jesus disputes with elders in temple. Hunt spent years in Jerusalem researching. Every costume, object archaeologically accurate. Pre-Raphaelite authenticity obsession.
why: Hunt's Jerusalem masterpiece. Spent years researching to make historically accurate! Every costume studied. Young Jesus amazing rabbis. Pre-Raphaelite authenticity taken to extreme. That detail!

title: April Love
desc: Young woman weeping in garden. Torn love letter at feet. Spring flowers contrast sadness. Pre-Raphaelite colour and emotion. Victorian sentiment.
why: Pre-Raphaelite emotion! She weeps amid spring beauty. Torn letter = love's end. Those flowers! That blue dress! Victorian melodrama painted with brilliant Pre-Raphaelite colour. Hughes capturing romantic sorrow.

title: The Long Engagement
desc: Couple in woods - engagement lasted so long their initials carved on tree have overgrown. Poor curate can't afford marriage. Victorian class barriers. Pre-Raphaelite social commentary.
why: Victorian tragedy of class! Engaged for years - too poor to marry. Tree grew over carved initials! That tells time passing. Pre-Raphaelites painting social problems. Love thwarted by economics.

title: The Last of England
desc: Couple emigrating from Britain. Looking back at white cliffs. Leaving forever. Brown based on friends emigrating to Australia. Pre-Raphaelite social realism. Victorian emigration trauma.
why: Victorian emigration tragedy! Leaving Britain forever. Based on Brown's friends fleeing to Australia. That last look at homeland! Hands clasped. Baby hidden under cloak. Pre-Raphaelite documenting social upheaval.

title: Work
desc: Every social class shown - laborers digging, rich ladies, intellectuals, poor children. Brown's epic of Victorian society. Thirteen years to complete. Social panorama.
why: Victorian society's totality! Took 13 years! Laborers, rich, poor, intellectuals all present. Pre-Raphaelite social analysis. Every class shown honestly. That detail! Victorian Britain complete.

title: The Romans Leaving Britain
desc: Romans abandon Britain. Ancient Britons reclaim land. Historical imagination. Pre-Raphaelite history painting. Brown's nationalism through history.
why: Pre-Raphaelite history painting! Romans leaving, Britons reclaiming. Victorian nationalism through ancient history. Brown painting British identity through imagined past.

title: Flaming June
location: Museo de Arte de Ponce, Puerto Rico
desc: Woman sleeps in orange dress. Oleander flowers. Mediterranean heat. Leighton's aesthetic classicism. Pure colour harmony. Decorative perfection.
why: Victorian aesthetic movement! That orange dress! Sleeping beauty in Mediterranean heat. Pure decoration - no story needed. Leighton's classical idealism. Colour and form as sole subjects. Sold for £100 in 1900s, millions now!

title: The Accolade
desc: Woman knights man with sword. Medieval ceremony romanticized. Victorian medievalism. Chivalric fantasy. Popular Victorian romanticism.
why: Victorian medieval fantasy! Woman dubbing knight. Romanticized chivalry. Victorian longing for medieval past. That ceremony! Popular Victorian taste for knights and ladies.

title: Godspeed
desc: Lady gives blessing to departing knight. Medieval romance. Victorian chivalric fantasy. Leighton's popular medievalism. Romantic departure.
why: Victorian romance! Knight departing, lady blessing. Medieval love idealized. Popular Victorian genre. That armor, that gown! Leighton's commercial success from romantic medievalism.

title: Hylas and the Nymphs
desc: Young Hylas lured by water nymphs. They pull him to doom. Waterhouse's dangerous female beauty theme. Pre-Raphaelite femme fatales. Erotic danger.
why: Waterhouse's dangerous beauties! Nymphs lure Hylas to death. Victorian anxiety about female sexuality. Pre-Raphaelite technique serving misogyny? Or just mythology? That water, those nymphs! Temporarily removed 2018 for being too sexist!

title: The Lady of Shalott Looking at Lancelot
desc: Lady at loom looking at Lancelot in mirror - breaking curse. Waterhouse painted her multiple times. Tennyson obsession. Medieval tragic romance.
why: Waterhouse's Tennyson obsession! She looks in mirror at Lancelot - curse activates! That moment of doomed love. Waterhouse painted her three times. Victorian romance addiction.

title: Circe Offering the Cup to Ulysses
desc: Sorceress Circe offers poisoned cup. Ulysses at feet. Waterhouse's dangerous women. Pre-Raphaelite femme fatale. Magic and seduction.
why: Waterhouse's witch! Circe turns men to pigs. That mirror behind showing future? Pre-Raphaelite dangerous beauty. Victorian male anxiety about female power visualised through mythology.

title: Echo and Narcissus
desc: Nymph Echo watches Narcissus admiring himself. Tragic one-sided love. Waterhouse's romantic mythology. Pre-Raphaelite beauty and sadness.
why: Waterhouse's tragic love! Echo fades watching Narcissus love himself. Greek tragedy via Pre-Raphaelite technique. That pool reflection! Victorian romantic suffering.

title: Cleopatra
desc: Cleopatra lounging in luxury. Oriental fantasy. Waterhouse's exotic sensuality. Pre-Raphaelite orientalism. Victorian Egypt obsession.
why: Victorian orientalism! Cleopatra as exotic fantasy. That luxury! Waterhouse's sensual exoticism. Victorian fascination with Egypt via Classical sources.

title: A Mermaid
desc: Mermaid on rocks combing hair, looking at pearl. Waterhouse's fantasy creatures. Pre-Raphaelite detail on mythological subject. Victorian fairy tale.
why: Waterhouse's fairy tale! Mermaid as realistic as possible. That tail! Victorian love of fantasy creatures painted realistically. Pre-Raphaelite technique serving imagination.

title: The Soul of the Rose
desc: Woman in medieval dress smells rose. Medieval garden. Waterhouse's romantic medievalism. Pre-Raphaelite sensuality and nostalgia.
why: Waterhouse's romantic medievalism! Woman lost in rose's scent. That medieval gown! Victorian longing for imagined past. Sensual and innocent combined.

title: The Danaides
desc: Women endlessly filling jars with holes. Greek punishment myth. Futile labour. Waterhouse's tragic women. Pre-Raphaelite mythology.
why: Eternal punishment visualised! Daughters murdered husbands - punished by filling leaking jars forever. Victorian morality through Greek myth. That futility!

title: Pandora
desc: Pandora with box about to open. Curiosity and doom. Waterhouse's dangerous female curiosity theme. Greek myth as Victorian warning.
why: Victorian anxiety about female curiosity! Pandora about to unleash evil. That box! Woman's curiosity causes humanity's suffering. Waterhouse painting misogyny via mythology?

title: Circe Invidiosa
desc: Jealous Circe pours poison transforming Scylla into monster. Female jealousy as destructive. Waterhouse's dark women. Magic and vengeance.
why: Female jealousy as monster-creating! Circe poisoning rival's bathing pool. Victorian male fear of female anger. That poison! Waterhouse's problematic but beautiful femme fatales.

title: Saint Cecilia
desc: Saint Cecilia playing organ with angels. Patron saint of music. Waterhouse's religious subjects rarer. Pre-Raphaelite spirituality and beauty.
why: Waterhouse doing religious subject! Saint Cecilia hearing heavenly music. Angels appear. Pre-Raphaelite technique serving Catholic imagery. Victorian spirituality.

title: Gather Ye Rosebuds While Ye May
desc: Young women gathering roses. Carpe diem theme. Youth and beauty fleeting. Waterhouse's melancholy beauty. Pre-Raphaelite garden scene.
why: Carpe diem painting! Gather roses before they fade. Youth fleeting. Waterhouse's bittersweet beauty. Victorian awareness of mortality through beauty.

title: Boreas
desc: North wind god Boreas as beautiful youth. Waterhouse's male beauty rare. Greek god of winter. Pre-Raphaelite male figure.
why: Waterhouse rarely painted male beauty! Boreas as youth. North wind personified. Pre-Raphaelite homoerotic possibility? Victorian male beauty.

title: The Favourites of the Emperor Honorius
desc: Roman emperor with pet doves while empire falls. Decadence and decline. Historical irony. Academic history painting.
why: Roman decline! Emperor cares more for doves than empire falling. Victorian moral about decadence. Historical painting as warning. That irony!

title: The Remorse of Nero After the Murder of His Mother
desc: Nero tormented after matricide. Roman history's horror. Waterhouse's early historical drama. Academic tradition.
why: Young Waterhouse doing history painting! Nero's guilt after killing mother. Roman horror. Victorian morality through ancient crime. Academic drama.

title: Consulting the Oracle
desc: Women consult oracle at temple. Ancient ritual. Waterhouse's archaeological accuracy. Academic classicism. Mystery and spirituality.
why: Waterhouse's archaeological painting! Greek oracle consulted. Victorian interest in ancient religion. That temple detail! Academic classicism.

title: The Magic Circle
desc: Witch creates magic circle with staff. Smoke, flames, spells. Waterhouse's supernatural. Pre-Raphaelite magic realism. Victorian occult interest.
why: Victorian occultism! Witch making magic circle. That smoke! Waterhouse painting supernatural seriously. Pre-Raphaelite detail on magical subject. Victorian séance era.

title: La Belle Dame sans Merci
desc: Fairy woman with doomed knight. Keats poem visualised. Waterhouse's femme fatale. Pre-Raphaelite dangerous beauty. Doomed love.
why: Keats visualised! Beautiful lady without mercy seduces knight to death. Victorian male anxiety about female sexuality. Pre-Raphaelite tragic romance.

title: Diogenes
location: Art Gallery of New South Wales
desc: Philosopher Diogenes with lantern seeking honest man. Classical philosopher. Waterhouse's early academic work. Cynic philosopher portrayed.
why: Waterhouse painting ancient philosophy! Diogenes searching for honest man with lantern. Victorian admiration for classical virtue. Academic figure study.

title: Sleep and His Half-Brother Death
desc: Greek personifications of sleep and death. Brothers from mythology. Waterhouse's early symbolism. Academic allegorical painting.
why: Early Waterhouse mythology! Sleep and Death as brothers. Victorian fascination with mortality. Academic allegory painting.

title: Mariamne Leaving the Judgement Seat of Herod
desc: Herod's wife Mariamne condemned. Biblical tragedy. Waterhouse's religious historical drama. Academic tradition.
why: Biblical drama! Mariamne condemned by jealous Herod. Victorian religious painting. Waterhouse's early historical religious works.

title: The Shrine
desc: Women at shrine praying. Religious devotion. Waterhouse's spiritual subjects. Pre-Raphaelite piety. Mediterranean setting.
why: Waterhouse spirituality! Women praying at shrine. Mediterranean Catholic tradition. Pre-Raphaelite religious feeling.

title: Tristan and Isolde
desc: Tragic lovers Tristan and Isolde. Medieval romance. Love potion dooms them. Waterhouse's late romanticism. Pre-Raphaelite tragedy.
why: Medieval tragic love! Love potion makes them love forbidden. Waterhouse painting medieval romance. Pre-Raphaelite nostalgia for chivalric past.

title: The Crystal Ball
desc: Woman gazes into crystal ball. Fortune telling. Victorian occultism. Waterhouse's supernatural. Pre-Raphaelite mystery.
why: Victorian séance culture! Woman scrying crystal ball. Occultism fashionable. Waterhouse painting supernatural practices. That crystal ball!

title: Destiny
desc: Figure representing fate. Allegorical painting. Waterhouse's symbolism. Pre-Raphaelite allegory. Fate personified.
why: Fate personified! Victorian symbolism. Waterhouse painting abstract concepts. Pre-Raphaelite allegory tradition.

title: Penelope and the Suitors
desc: Faithful Penelope at loom. Suitors court her while Odysseus absent. Greek fidelity story. Waterhouse's classical subjects. Victorian virtue.
why: Faithful wife waiting! Penelope weaving, suitors harassing. Greek virtue story. Waterhouse painting ideal Victorian wife through Greek myth.

title: Ulysses and the Sirens
desc: Odysseus tied to mast, sailors with wax in ears. Sirens sing from rocks. Resisting temptation. Waterhouse's classical adventure. Victorian self-control.
why: Greek adventure! Odysseus resisting Sirens. Victorian morality - self-control through bondage! Those sirens! Waterhouse painting temptation and resistance.

title: Jason and Medea
desc: Jason and sorceress Medea. Dangerous love. Medea will murder their children. Waterhouse's toxic relationships. Greek tragedy.
why: Toxic relationship! Medea will kill their kids. Waterhouse painting doomed love. Greek tragedy via Pre-Raphaelite technique. Victorian relationship anxiety.

title: Ariadne
desc: Ariadne abandoned on Naxos. Theseus sailed away. Betrayed love. Waterhouse's abandoned women theme. Greek tragedy romanticized.
why: Abandoned woman! Theseus betrayed her after she saved him. Waterhouse painting female victimhood. Greek tragedy as Victorian sentiment.

title: The Siren
desc: Siren on rocks with lyre. Singing sailor to doom. Waterhouse's dangerous female beauty. Pre-Raphaelite femme fatale. Mythological seductress.
why: Dangerous female beauty! Siren luring sailors to death. Victorian male anxiety painted beautifully. That lyre! Waterhouse's recurring dangerous women theme.

title: Nymphs Finding the Head of Orpheus
desc: Nymphs discover Orpheus's severed head still singing. Greek myth's horror. Waterhouse's darker subjects. Pre-Raphaelite macabre.
why: Greek horror! Orpheus torn apart by maenads, head floats singing. Waterhouse painting mythology's violence. Pre-Raphaelite beauty meets horror.

title: Flora
desc: Roman goddess of flowers. Classical beauty. Waterhouse's decorative classicism. Pre-Raphaelite aesthetic painting. Pure beauty subject.
why: Classical beauty! Flora as spring goddess. Pure aesthetic painting. Waterhouse decorative classicism. Victorian love of classical forms.

title: A Roman Offering
desc: Roman woman making offering at altar. Classical devotion. Waterhouse's archaeological accuracy. Academic ancient world. Religious ritual.
why: Roman religious ritual! Victorian reconstruction of ancient world. Archaeological accuracy. Academic classicism painting pagan religion.

title: Phyllis and Demophoon
desc: Phyllis turns to tree embracing Demophoon. Ovid's metamorphosis. Burne-Jones's dreamlike classicism. Pre-Raphaelite transformation mythology.
why: Burne-Jones mythology! Woman becoming tree. Ovid visualised. Pre-Raphaelite dreamy classicism. Transformation as female victimhood metaphor?

title: King Cophetua and the Beggar Maid
desc: King kneels before beggar maid. Love transcending class. Burne-Jones's romantic idealism. Pre-Raphaelite medieval fantasy. Victorian class fantasy.
why: Victorian class fantasy! King loves beggar. Romantic idealism. Burne-Jones's medieval dreamworld. That coronation scene! Class barriers dissolved by beauty.

title: The Golden Stairs
desc: Procession of women descending stairs. Musical instruments. Burne-Jones's pure aesthetic. No story - just beauty. Pre-Raphaelite decoration.
why: Pure aestheticism! No story - just beautiful women descending. Burne-Jones creating beauty without narrative. That procession! Aesthetic movement perfection.

title: The Beguiling of Merlin
desc: Nimue entraps wizard Merlin. Female magic overpowering male. Burne-Jones's dangerous women. Pre-Raphaelite Arthurian legend. Victorian gender anxiety.
why: Female power over male! Nimue trapping Merlin with his own magic. Victorian male anxiety about female power. Burne-Jones painting sexual politics via Arthurian legend.

title: The Mirror of Venus
desc: Venus and attendants gaze into pool. Classical female beauty multiplied. Burne-Jones's decorative classicism. Pre-Raphaelite aesthetic perfection.
why: Aesthetic beauty! Multiple women gazing at reflections. Burne-Jones creating beauty for beauty's sake. Classical setting, timeless figures. Pure Pre-Raphaelite decoration.

title: Love Among the Ruins
desc: Lovers embrace amid ancient ruins. Love survives civilizations' fall. Burne-Jones's romantic symbolism. Pre-Raphaelite ruins and romance.
why: Love outlasts empires! Couple embraces amid fallen civilization. Victorian romantic symbolism. Burne-Jones painting love's triumph over time's destruction.

title: The Star of Bethlehem
desc: Angels procession to nativity. Burne-Jones's religious subjects. Pre-Raphaelite spirituality. Victorian Christian art. Medieval inspired angels.
